questions.question_text: What must be obtained before an investigation is carried out at a location?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Correct: A search warrant is required to legally search a location for evidence.
B. Incorrect: A subpoena compels documents or testimony, not a physical search.
C. Incorrect: Habeas corpus pertains to unlawful detention, not investigations.
D. Incorrect: Modus operandi refers to a suspect's method of operation, not legal authorization.

The correct answer is A. Search warrant.
A search warrant is a legal document issued by a judge or magistrate that authorizes law enforcement or investigators to conduct a search of a specific location for evidence related to a crime or investigation. It is typically required before an investigation can be carried out at a location, especially if the location is private property.
A subpoena (B) is a legal order to produce evidence or testify in court, but it is not required to initiate an investigation.
Habeas corpus (C) is a legal principle that protects individuals from unlawful detention, but it is not related to the search and seizure of evidence.
Modus operandi (D) refers to the methods or techniques used by a criminal to commit a crime, but it is not a legal requirement for conducting an investigation.

questions.question_text: Paul is a computer forensics investigator working for Tyler & Company Consultants. Paul has been called upon to help investigate a computer hacking ring broken up by the local police. Paul begins to inventory the PCs found in the hackers hideout. Paul then comes across a PDA left by them that is attached to a number of different peripheral devices. What is the first step that Paul must take with the PDA to ensure the integrity of the investigation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A. Incorrect: Placing in an antistatic bag is important but not the first step.
B. Incorrect: Disconnecting devices before documentation risks losing crucial information.
C. Incorrect: Powering off devices prematurely might lead to loss of volatile data.
D. Correct: Documenting and photographing ensures the chain of custody and captures the setup for evidence integrity.

choices.D: Photograph and document the peripheral devices
choices.A: Place PDA, including all devices, in an antistatic bag
choices.C: Power off all devices if currently on

questions.question_text: During an investigation, an employee was found to have deleted harassing emails that were sent to someone else. The company was using Microsoft Exchange and had message tracking enabled. Where could the investigator search to find the message tracking log file on the Exchange server?

discussion.content: By default, the message tracking log files exist in %ExchangeInstallPath%TransportRoles\Logs\MessageTracking. The folder contains log files with different names, following the convention MSGTRKServiceyyyyMMdd-nnnn.log. These logs record mail activity as messages flow through the transport pipeline on Mailbox servers and Edge Transport servers. To search these logs, the investigator can use the Get-MessageTrackingLog cmdlet in the Exchange Management Shell or explore the Delivery reports tab in the Exchange admin center12. So, the correct answer is C. C:\Exchsrvr\Message Tracking\servername.log.

Selected Answer: A
This is a very outdated question. 
The sole correct answer for old 2003 Exchange server directory is: 
A - C:\Program Files\Exchsrvr\<ServerName>.log

I can't find any information about "message tracking" in CHFI v10 book. On Microsoft Learn site I found:
%ExchangeInstallPath%TransportRoles\Logs\MessageTracking. 

So answers B,C and D are not correct at all.
That's why I propose answer A is the correct outdated answer for outdated question.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow/transport-logs/message-tracking?view=exchserver-2019

This is a very outdated question. 
The sole correct answer for old 2003 Exchange server directory is: 
A - C:\Program Files\Exchsrvr\<ServerName>.log

I can't find any information about "message tracking" in CHFI v10 book. On Microsoft Learn site I found:
%ExchangeInstallPath%TransportRoles\Logs\MessageTracking. 

So answers B,C and D are not correct at all.
That's why I propose answer A is the correct outdated answer for outdated question.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mail-flow/transport-logs/message-tracking?view=exchserver-2019

A:
The locations of the log files are configurable, but by default, message tracking logs are stored in the Exchange server installation location; specifically:
For Exchange 2003: C:\Program Files\Exchsrvr\<ServerName>.log
For Exchange 2007: C:\Program Files\Microsoft\Exchange Server\TransportRoles\ Logs\MessageTracking.

Selected Answer: C
C:\Exchsrvr\Message Tracking\servername.log. In Microsoft Exchange, message tracking logs are stored in the Message Tracking folder located in the Exchsrvr folder on the Exchange server. The file path for the message tracking log file is typically C:\Exchsrvr\Message Tracking\servername.log, where "servername" is the name of the Exchange server.
All of these answers are incorrect according to quick Google search, but if I had to guess I would say 'c' is the closest to being accurate. I suspect this question is very old and outdated.

questions.question_text: Paraben Lockdown device uses which operating system to write hard drive data?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A. Incorrect: Mac OS is not used in Paraben Lockdown devices.
B. Incorrect: Red Hat (a Linux distribution) is not used in this device.
C. Incorrect: Unix is not the operating system utilized by Paraben Lockdown.
D. Correct: Paraben Lockdown devices use a Windows-based operating system for writing and managing hard drive data.

Selected Answer: D
Paraben recommends the use of Paraben's Lockdown because Windows writes to any drive upon bootup

questions.question_text: What technique is used by JPEGs for compression?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A. Incorrect: ZIP is a general-purpose compression algorithm, not specific to JPEGs.
B. Incorrect: TCD is not related to JPEG compression.
C. Correct: JPEGs use DCT (Discrete Cosine Transform) to compress images by transforming spatial data into frequency data, reducing redundancies.
D. Incorrect: TIFF-8 is a file format, not a compression technique.

JPEGs use the Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) technique for compression. This mathematical transformation converts spatial image data into frequency domain coefficients, reducing redundancy and achieving compression.

C:
The key to the JPEG baseline compression process is a mathematical transformation known as the Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT)
